tweets.text:
A mile of the River Lugg has been bulldozed to destruction.
Bankside trees grubbed out & burnt.
Riverbed scraped out.
Meanders reprofiled.
Disaster for downstream wildlife.
This was an SSSI.
No consent was sought. 
@EnvAgency must surely prosecute this.
RT
https://t.co/cSBhrR2nDW

We‚Äôve used our powers of entry at the River Lugg #Herefordshire incident

14 specialist officers from @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @WMerciaPolice @HfdsCouncil now on site gathering information & evidence. https://t.co/LLCOFQHCox
Five years since #StormDesmond hit #Cumbria, new flood defences are offering better protection to at least 2,000 properties according to the @EnvAgencyNW. https://t.co/RN7hvKsjQV
@WestCumbriaRT @EnvAgencyNW @NTWestLakes That's incredible! Did you have to add gravel?

"Be in no doubt that anything less than a prosecution and full restoration of the river, paid for by the perpetrator, will be acceptable‚Äù.

@EnvAgency and others want to prove they are fit for the 21st century? Here's your chance. https://t.co/ji0wmcYyhf

BEFORE & AFTER

Appalling #EcoVandalism at The #RiverLugg SSSI #Herefordshire

THIS IS ILLEGAL ACTIVITY

So it's a CRITICAL TEST CASE for environmental enforcement by @NaturalEngland @EnvAgency @DefraGovUK

The @WildlifeTrusts will be making sure appropriate legal action is taken https://t.co/U8lt4ZuX1t
Our piece by @GlassJet on the depressing news of the destruction of a stretch of Herefordshire's River Lugg  @EnvAgency @WildlifeTrusts  https://t.co/CaNN4WVP5J

Following widespread condemnation of the ecovandalism on the #RiverLugg, the EA have pinned this tweet at the top of their feed. Tonne of bricks, please. Essential to send a signal even the most ignorant and deep-pocketed landowners can understand. Well done @HerefordshireWT https://t.co/bIOGJpcicx

We're mounting a wide-ranging investigation into reports of damage to the #RiverLugg, which is protected through SSSI status. We're treating this very seriously, working with @NaturalEngland & @ForestryComm who have taken immediate action to prevent any further works at the site. https://t.co/bvhnTETfal
We're taking reports of environmental damage to the #SSSI at the #RiverLugg very seriously, and are working with @EnvAgency and @ForestryComm to take immediate action. https://t.co/27DINp3vD7

üì¢Brilliant news to share from #StaffsSUNRISE today! @PaulNGaskell from @WildTroutTrust visited our new river channels at #VictoriaGround & @StaffsUni & found several brown trout 'nests' (redds) - meaning they're using them for spawning already!   
@EnvAgencyMids @SoTCityCouncil https://t.co/CIiefX7mqC

Guest Blog: How Nature Dies by Alistair Gammell https://t.co/TwtWsfjEUO

@EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @HMWTBadger @NorthHertsDC @Feargal_Sharkey @WildTroutTrust @AffinityWater #hitchin #herts #abstraction #aquifer #chalkstream #river #oughton #pirton https://t.co/VcxTSA0LE2

urls.title: Guest blog - How nature dies by Alistair Gammell - Mark Avery
urls.description: Alistair Gammell worked for RSPB for 40 years and was closely involved in the drafting of the Birds and Habitats Directives and for growing RSPB‚Äôs international work. He was RSPB‚Äôs first International Director and retired from RSPB in 2009. He then worked to successfully establish large scale fully protected marine reserves in the seas around the British Indian Ocean Territory and Pitcairn Island. He is a passionate nature conservationist and fly fisherman (alistairgammell@yahoo.co.uk) Oughton Head is a

tweets.text:
@JackPerksPhoto @CatchmentDove @EnvAgencyMids @SalmonTroutCons @Trent_R_Trust @theriverstrust @TrentGateway @NEEastMidlands @StaffsWildlife @DerbysWildlife @TrentCaba @IYS_Atlantic @MissingSalmon @AST_Salmon Sensational footage!!! Five years ago #StormDesmond caused devastation in
#Lancashire.

Thousands of homes and businesses were flooded.

Our climate champion @janehardyjones was a student
@lancasteruni. She tells her story and addresses what we can do about climate change and flooding.

#BBCPlanetNorth https://t.co/cqHwUYDN2z

tweets.text: May I ask... @EnvAgency When did you add SHARKS to the River Freshney, please? What was the rationale behind it? https://t.co/nrOiibjIBV

5 years since Storm Desmond, the @EnvAgencyNW says new flood defences offer better protection to at least 2,000 properties in Cumbria. It also says more flood protection work is planned for the county over the next five years.

The new Nov 2020 Burneside, Staveley and Ings & upstream measures newsletter includes info on the benefits & timescales of the #floodscheme as well as details of #UpstreamMeasures that will be implemented. Download here: https://t.co/YsDVn7ozwT

#Cumbria #flooding @EnvAgencyNW https://t.co/CMEb32rcC2

tweets.text:
We're taking this incident at a SSSI very seriously and are investigating reports of damage to the #RiverLugg. We're investigating in partnership with 
@NaturalEngland & @ForestryComm https://t.co/1cG6B6hOui

In 2015 Storm Desmond hit Cumbria flooding many areas including the town of #Egremont. 
 
5 years on and #TeamEA are investing 12 million on a flood scheme for the town with works ongoing to better protect 220 properties from flooding. 
 
For more info - https://t.co/UibqT7Itw6 https://t.co/kDcqp2sM3E

urls.title: Cumbria | The Flood Hub
urls.description: This local spaces area will provide information o n our aim to manage flood risk on a catchment scale from Source to Sea. In this section we will introduce you to Cumbria Strategic Flood Partnership, a collective of organisations that coordinates all flood risk management planning and delivery and detailed information on Flood Risk Management Schemes being delivered.
